data:
Lochgilphead Primary School forms part of Lochgilphead Joint Campus, a 3-18 campus that includes a Pre-5 Unit, Primary School and Secondary School.  The school is situated on the west coast of Scotland and the Primary currently provides education for 228 pupils across 9 classes.  A Learning Centre is also incorporated within the school catering for children with complex additional needs.
The Primary School are currently delivering French to pupils throughout the school as part of the Languages 1+2 initiative.  Two members of staff have been previously trained through the Modern Languages In Primary Schools (MLPS) programme and all staff were recently trained in the use of the Power Language Schools platform.  This training has enabled staff to increase their knowledge and confidence in delivering French to all classes.  
The school is in the second year of introducing the first of the languages for Languages 1+2.  French was chosen as language 1 and all staff have been trained in the use of the Power Language Schools platform to support the teaching of French.  The staff have varying levels of confidence regarding the teaching of French with some staff having no previous French knowledge to draw on.  Training has been completed at local cluster level with support from trained local authority colleagues and also at school level with more experienced staff supporting those colleagues who are perhaps lacking in confidence.  As the pupils progress with their knowledge of French, the staff competences and methodology are constantly having to improve also.  Further staff training and support has therefore been identified as an area for development and it is planned to be included in the school's improvement plan.  The European dimension of learning another language has also been identified as an area for development.
An LFEE French immersion course has been identified as a suitable development opportunity to support the current needs of the school.  A member of staff, Mrs Lees was chosen as the most appropriate person to complete the training.  Mrs Lees is an experienced class teacher and has completed the French MLPS course.  She is committed to promoting the teaching and embedding of French within the school and this international experience will further develop her skill set so that she can support and train colleagues both within the school and within the local cluster. 
Mrs Elizabeth Lees is an experienced class teacher and has been delivering French throughout the school for a number of years having previously completed the MLPS training.  She is currently teaching a Primary 2 class and is embedding French language teaching throughout the school day.  She has supported other staff in the teaching of French through the introduction of Languages 1+2 and has included embedding French in the classroom as part of her professional development.  As the LFEE Immersion Course is GTCS accredited, attendance at the course will allow Mrs Lees to apply for accreditation and further her professional development.
Local authority staff specialising in the delivery of Languages 1+2 will support Mrs Lees both prior to and following attendance at the immersion course.  
Prior to attendance on the LFEE immersion course in July it is hoped that Mrs Lees will spend time with some native speakers to develop confidence with use of language which may be required on the journey.
During the course it is hoped to extend cultural awareness of the region being visited as well as fluency in delivering class lessons.
Following the course it is anticipated that Mrs Lees will deliver training to colleagues within the school and local cluster through twilight sessions and workshops.  Making use of new resources, ICT and the Power Language Schools platform will enhance and develop the methodology for teaching French as well as boosting the confidence of the staff who have less background knowledge in French, ensuring the successful delivery of the Languages 1+2 initiative.
A parents' workshop will be provided, allowing parents to develop their knowledge and understanding of Languages 1+2 and how they can support their children in the learning of an additional language.
Mrs Lees also plans to introduce a European dimension through the use of the e-Twinning tool in order to develop links with a French school, strengthening international awareness.  These links will be developed with the children through an after school/lunchtime club.
The development of the Languages 1+2 initiative will be included in the school's improvement plan for the following session.  Having the opportunity to be immersed in the culture of France and have the experience of speaking French with native speakers in a variety of contexts will undoubtedly raise the confidence of Mrs Lees in the use of spoken French. This increased skill set will then transfer to the pupils and staff that she works with.
Atlantic Oakwoods - Restoration of Atlantic Oakwoods

Moss and lichen-rich old oak woodlands are an Annex I habitat type restricted to Britain and Ireland where this is the climax 'temperate rainforest' community of Europe's Atlantic coast. In Britain it is restricted to sites in the west of the country, many of which have been subject to management - including forestry practices - which have degraded their nature conservation interest. Underplanting and replacement of broadleaved deciduous species by exotic conifers; invasive plants like rhododendron; increasing pressure from deer browsing which reduces natural regeneration; and in some areas high visitor numbers, are among the key threats to these ancient oak woodlands.

The project was concerned with improving the habitat condition in seven of the most extensive Atlantic woodlands in Britain, ranging from Loch Maree in the far north-west of Scotland, through the popular Loch Lomond woodlands within easy reach of Glasgow, to Borrowdale woods in the Lake District and Meirionnydd oakwoods in north-west Wales. Together they cover nearly 4,900 ha of Atlantic oakwood habitat.

At each site, a set of management targets was to be established based on the most important perceived threats. Actions would target the clearance of around 690 ha of exotic conifers and broadleaves, treatment of around 405 ha to eradicate rhododendron, and treatment of a further area of over 370 ha to control bracken. Another important activity would be controlling grazing - particularly by sheep, deer and feral goats through a mixture of stock fencing - over 60 km - and deer culling. The effectiveness of the various measures was to be monitored and assessed and the results disseminated on a web-site.
Development of an innovative, cost-effective environmetally friendly closed cage for sea-based fish farming

ClosedFishCage will focus on the development of a closed, escape proof, constant volume, sea-based cage for fish farming. Among the project’s innovative elements are a very durable and flexible polymer plastic net pen, a predator guard, a control system, easy set-up and replacement of damaged cage parts. The technological solutions involved in the sea-based cage will preserve advantages of land-based fish farming while at the same time taking advantage of the cost efficiency of seabased fish farming. Furthermore, the new cage system will be both substantially more cost-efficient and also more environmentally friendly existing fish farming technologies. Consequently, ClosedFishCage will result in the development of new, more appropriate technology enabling increased use of sea-based fish farming and thus also greatly improve possibilities of fish farming technology.  The market for fish, and especially European farmed fish, continues to grow. However, EU catches have dropped in recent years, aquaculture production has remained stable, and the current supply of fish is therefore not enough to cover market demand. Furthermore, as a result of a combination of near depletion of certain EU fishery stocks, reduced annual catch quotas, and reduced fishing fleets, Member States of the Union are becoming increasingly dependent on imports from third countries. ClosedFishCage will not only improve the competitiveness of SMEs in the aquaculture sector but also safeguard the potential production of good quality fish, in sufficient quantities, at competitive prices.

Argyll & Bute and Amberg-Sulzbach have been twinned regions since 1967. Over that time numerous groups of German young people have visited Argyll and there have been a number of reciprocal visits by Argyll & Bute young people to Bavaria either through school Exchanges or music Exchanges. The last Youth Exchange between the two regions took place in 1995. 
 
In 2015, Argyll & Bute hosted a delegation of German Youth Workers, teachers and Volunteers from Amberg-Sulzbach with the main focus to re-establish Youth Exchanges between both areas. During the week long visit, the Amberg-Sulzbach delegation meet with Youth Services staff and young people showcasing Youth Work programmes and meeting partner agencies across the authority. During this visit the idea of an exchange was discussed with local Youth Forums and groups from Oban & Bute took part in the first leg of the exchange in Amberg-Sulzbach in August 2016 and in the hosting Exchange in Oban and Bute in April 2017. In total, 6 staff members, 2 of which were volunteers and 25 young people aged 12-19 took part, 10 from Argyll & Bute and 15 from Amberg-Sulzbach. The objective of the exchange was to explore issues around health & wellbeing in both countries including young people's mental health. The results showed similarities in factors affecting young people's Health & Wellbeing and mental health between the Scottish and German groups.

This Exchange will build on the relationship with the KoJa Amberg-Sulzbach and will involve the areas of Bute, Campbeltown and Helensburgh from Argyll & Bute. This will give the German young people a greater understanding of living in a rural region and the transport challenges faced by communities across the region. The first stage of the Exchange will explore the themes of Environment which is relevant to Argyll & Bute due to its coast line,  use of renewable energy sources and the zero carbon/recycling targets. In addition to the Environment, we will look at the integration of refugees. This is particularly relevant to both Armberg-Sulzbach and Argyll & Bute given the resettlement of Syrian Refugees in both countries. We will explore the issues facing migrants and the everyday barriers that they face in a new country, local attitudes towards their resettlement, their support programme and investigate any experiences of Anti-racism, Hate Crime or Anti-Semitism and will compare and contrast the experiences of refugees in Argyll & Bute and Amberg-Sulzbach. Exploring this issue in depth during the exchange may help give some young people a greater understanding of refugees circumstances and change their attitudes, which are often formed by what they read on social media, hear from their peers or from family. Often these are negative and extreme views towards refugees.

The longer term benefits of this Exchange will hopefully lead to many more future Exchanges and collaborations between the two regions involving different areas of Argyll & Bute and strengthen the relationship between the Youth Workers
Business Gateway Local Growth Accelerator Programme - Argyll and Bute
To provide support SMEs who demonstrate growth ambition, and deepen support available to those already growing.
Scottish raised bogs - Restoration of Scottish raised bogs

Since the start of the nineteenth century the extent of primary, active, lowland raised bog in the UK decreased from 95,000 ha to 8,100 ha, a decline of 85%. Two thirds of the remaining area is found in Scotland, and, despite the scale of destruction, Scotland still holds a significant proportion of raised bogs in good condition.

The project focused on 45% of the existing resource in the UK within eleven SCIs (12 individual sites). All of the sites - whether large or small, private or public – had been subject to human intervention at some stage through peat cutting, drainage works, tree planting, scrub encroachment and grazing pressure. This is because raised bogs have traditionally been viewed as unproductive areas suitable only for ‘improvement’ through drainage and reclamation. They have little intrinsic economic value, especially since their use for domestic peat has all but disappeared.

The development and objectives are divided into six priorities.
1. Quality assurance
2. Expansion of the existing network with partner companies in EU countries
3. Social commitment
4. Strengthening the idea of the European Union
5. Public relations - dissemination of Erasmus + projects
6. Getting to know and appreciate new places and cultures
 
1. Quality Assurance:
School education must be comparable with other vocational education and training systems. Educational objectives and learning outcomes must be clearly described. The allocation of ECVET points for the learning results must be carried out by a superior expert team uniformly for all schools; teachers of the HLW Rankweil are ready to be part of working teams.

The qualifications which our pupils have acquired during their internship abroad will be made visible by the partner companies and the HLW. Practice-oriented teaching while incorporating the knowledge and working techniques acquired abroad is implemented.

The acquisition of language certificates (DELF, BEC, DELE and CILS) and specialised certificates (boys' chefs and cheese chefs) increases the quality of the training and must be promoted and financially supported.

Motivation of the pupils to participate in language competitions.

Teachers must constantly update their knowledge and skills and are encouraged to pursue professional development at home and abroad.

Teachers are motivated to complete internships during their summer holidays both in local and foreign companies.
 
2. Expansion of partnerships with foreign companies
In recent years, the Board of Trustees has been able to establish a network of 40 partner companies abroad. Currently there are only partnerships with tourism companies. The network is to be expanded with other industries.
 
3. Social commitment
When engaging in social services, pupils should show responsibility for the well-being of people in Europe. We want to deepen our commitment and further develop the project “Street Children” in Romania and Bulgaria.
 
4. Strengthening the idea of the European Union
The philosophy of the EU and its importance and impact should be increasingly explored in teaching. Students of the third or fourth year are to visit the EU Parliament in Strasbourg as part of an excursion. Increased travelling exhibitions in the school. EU experts as speakers to the school.

5. Public relations and dissemination of the project should be substantially improved. A focus group is to be appointed for this. New media will be increasingly involved.
 
6. In the case of excursions, language, culture, and sports weeks, the students should get to know new places and cultural and sports facilities in the EU.
 
The number of participants in his project has remained stable for the last 8 years at our school. More than 92% of the students have completed the compulsory three-month internship at a hotel abroad.

In order to increase the quality of the foreign exchange program, cooperation with the companies has to be intensified. The hosting partners need be more involved in our preparations. In the future we want to stress the "reflection on the results of our work". This reflection needs to be done on various levels: self-reflection by the pupils, assessment or reflection by the company, recognition of the internships by different bodies of the school.
Schlüsselqualifikationen und Kompetenzen im Lernort Hotel erwerben

As a public school the HLW Rankweil is the only school of its kind in Vorarlberg. Each of the five grade levels are separated into three classes. Roughly 60 teachers are responsible for the education of all 480 students. Students at the HLW acquire an extensive, well-rounded education in preparation for further study at the university level, as well as technical and vocational colleges. The knowledge and skills that students gain enable them to exercise professionalism in all areas of business, management and the social and health services. The practice-oriented method of training at the HLW is supported by a required 3-month internship, which takes place between the 3rd and 4th grade.

The maturity and diploma examination from vocational secondary schools and educational institutions, such as the HLW, represents a graduation standard that corresponds to that of the "Short Cycle Higher Education Programmes" (Bologna process). This is also verified by the regulation in the European policy 2005/36/EC on the recognition of professional qualifications and through comparisons in the European Qualifications Framework (EQF).

In the summer of 2014, 91 out of 93 students going into their fourth year at the HLW Rankweil will partake in the Erasmus+ mobility project and complete their required internship at a European hotel abroad. At the HLW, students begin learning French in the first year and carry on with their English training (after four years in lower secondary schools). They continue their foreign language education by learning a third modern language in their third year, when they can choose to take either Spanish or Italian. Students can choose where they want to complete their internship based on which languages they study. All students complete their internship at a hotel, where they are introduced primarily to the areas of service, housekeeping, kitchen and reception. Through practical experience, students get to know companies, develop their own business mindsets and deepen their understanding of good work ethics and business procedures.

During their internship, students also have the possibility to use and expand their foreign language capabilities working in the hotels and in every-day situations outside of work. The students have the chance to work as a team, as well as gain experience working alone. They learn to critically analyze their work attitudes and results and to scrutinize their work ethics. Individual, independent and lateral thinking, the acquisition and expansion of trade and methodological skills and social and personal skills are an essential building block for a successful start to their career or for further education at colleges and universities. The quality of education is enriched by the implementation of mobility projects and collaborating with international companies. Teachers and management are required to respond quickly and flexibly to changing economic conditions in the businesses, which result in the changing of demands from the employees. The internship leads to the increased mobility of our students, to the opening of the labour market and to a greater range of jobs, and is associated with the higher level of employment rates of our graduates.

In accordance with paragraph 65 section 1 of the School Introduction Act (SCHUG), the Kuratorium in the HLW is an Institution that seeks cooperation within the advanced school community in order to foster and promote a closer relationship between vocational schools and economic life. The Kuratorium can make various suggestions and recommendations and fosters and supports the education and well-being of the HLW's students and graduates. Consequently the HLW students graduate as young adults highly qualified for the workforce.As a public school the HLW Rankweil is the only school of its kind in Vorarlberg. Each of the five grade levels are separated into classes. Roughly56 teachers are responsible for the education of all 475 students ( 473 girls and 2 boys) Students at the HLW acquire an extensive, well-rounded education in preparation for further study at the university level, as well as technical and vocational colleges. The knowledge and skills that students gain enable them to exercise professionalism in all areas of business, management and the social and health services. The practice-oriented method of training at the HLW is supported by a required 3-month internship, which takes place between the 3rd and 4th grade.The maturity and diploma examination from vocational secondary schools and educational institutions, such as the HLW, represents a graduation standard that corresponds to that of the “Short Cycle Higher Education Programmes” (Bologna process). This is also verified by the regulation in the European policy 2005/36/EC on the recognition of professional qualifications and through comparisons in the European Qualifications Framework (EQF).In the summer of 2016, 85out of 90 students going into their fourth year at the HLW Rankweil will partake in the Erasmus+ mobility project and complete their required internship at a European hotel abroad. At the HLW, students begin learning French in the first year and carry on with their English training (after four years in lower secondary schools). They continue their foreign language education by learning a third modern language in their third year, when they can choose to take either Spanish or Italian. Economics and Physical Education are taught bilingually (German, French, English). Furthermore we offer a separate optional subject "Multilingualism in Education".Students can choose where they want to complete their internship based on which languages they study. All students complete their internship at a hotel, where they are introduced primarily to the areas of service, housekeeping, kitchen and reception. Through practical experience, students get to know companies, develop their own business mindsets and deepen their understanding of good work ethics and business procedures.During their internship, students also have the possibility to use and expand their foreign language capabilities working in the hotels and in every-day situations outside of work. The students have the chance to work as a team, as well as gain experience working alone. They learn to critically analyse their work attitudes and results and to scrutinize their work ethics. Individual, independent and lateral thinking, the acquisition and expansion of trade and methodological skills and social and personal skills are an essential building block for a successful start to their career or for further education at colleges and universities. The quality of education is enriched by the implementation of mobility projects and collaborating with international companies. Teachers and management are required to respond quickly and flexibly to changing economic conditions in the businesses, which result in the changing of demands from the employees. The internship leads to the increased mobility of our students and graduates. The trainees’ progress can be visualized by using national documents like e.g. Europass - Mobility, Memorandum of Understanding, Learning Agreements and Personal Transcripts and so the comparison with other vocational trainings is possible.  This leads to the opening of the labour market and to a greater range of jobs, and is associated with the higher level of employment rates of our graduates.OSL (Online Lunguistic Support) is an excellent support for our VET students. The assesment test, which they idally take at the beginning of their practical traininig, shows them which language level they are at and which areas need to be improved. Then, they have the possibility to use the OLS language courses throughout their whole practical training. This gives them the chance to work on their language skills individually and it helps them to improve their overall language performance.
Schülerinnen der HLW Rankweil erwerben Kompetenzen im Kontext der Arbeit

In accordance with paragraph 65 section 1 of the School Introduction Act (SCHUG), the Kuratorium in the HLW is an Institution that seeks cooperation within the advanced school community in order to foster and promote a closer relationship between vocational schools and economic life. The Kuratorium can make various suggestions and recommendations and fosters and supports the education and well-being of the HLW's students and graduates. Consequently the HLW students graduate as young adults highly qualified for the workforce.

As a public school the HLW Rankweil is the only school of its kind in Vorarlberg. Each of the five grade levels are separated into classes. Roughly 60 teachers are responsible for the education of all 476 students ( 475 girls and 1 boy) Students at the HLW acquire an extensive, well-rounded education in preparation for further study at the university level, as well as technical and vocational colleges. The knowledge and skills that students gain enable them to exercise professionalism in all areas of business, management and the social and health services. The practice-oriented method of training at the HLW is supported by a required 3-month internship, which takes place between the 3rd and 4th grade.

The maturity and diploma examination from vocational secondary schools and educational institutions, such as the HLW, represents a graduation standard that corresponds to that of the “Short Cycle Higher Education Programmes” (Bologna process). This is also verified by the regulation in the European policy 2005/36/EC on the recognition of professional qualifications and through comparisons in the European Qualifications Framework (EQF).

In the summer of 2015, 86 out of 92 students going into their fourth year at the HLW Rankweil will partake in the Erasmus+ mobility project and complete their required internship at a European hotel abroad. At the HLW, students begin learning French in the first year and carry on with their English training (after four years in lower secondary schools). They continue their foreign language education by learning a third modern language in their third year, when they can choose to take either Spanish or Italian. Economics and Physical Education are taught bilingually (German, French, English). Furthermore we offer a separate optional subject "Multilingualism in Education".

Students can choose where they want to complete their internship based on which languages they study. All students complete their internship at a hotel, where they are introduced primarily to the areas of service, housekeeping, kitchen and reception. 

Through practical experience, students get to know companies, develop their own business mindsets and deepen their understanding of good work ethics and business procedures.

During their internship, students also have the possibility to use and expand their foreign language capabilities working in the hotels and in every-day situations outside of work. 

The students have the chance to work as a team, as well as gain experience working alone. They learn to critically analyse their work attitudes and results and to scrutinize their work ethics. Individual, independent and lateral thinking, the acquisition and expansion of trade and methodological skills and social and personal skills are an essential building block for a successful start to their career or for further education at colleges and universities. 

The quality of education is enriched by the implementation of mobility projects and collaborating with international companies. Teachers and management are required to respond quickly and flexibly to changing economic conditions in the businesses, which result in the changing of demands from the employees. 

The internship leads to the increased mobility of our students and graduates. The trainees’ progress can be visualized by using national documents like e.g. Europass - Mobility, Memorandum of Understanding, Learning Agreements and Personal Transcripts and so the comparison with other vocational trainings is possible.  This leads to the opening of the labour market and to a greater range of jobs, and is associated with the higher level of employment rates of our graduates.
